description.plain:
Benjamin Coyle-Larner, better known by the stage name Loyle Carner. His stage name was originally going to be Mowgli but became Loyle Carner because he suffers from dyslexia and would accidentally spell his name as Loyle-Carner not Coyle-Larner as a kid.

Loyle Carner is a British rap music artist and actor from South London. His sound has been described by NME as ‘sensitive and eloquent’ and by The Guardian as ‘confessional hip-hop’. Loyle Carner has toured with the likes MF DOOM, Joey Badass and Kate Tempest and has also played at many UK festivals including Glastonbury. In October 2015 he played on Huw Stephens' BBC Radio 1 show as part of their Piano Sessions series.

songs.full_title: Florence by Loyle Carner (Ft.  kwes.)
songs.title: Florence

description.plain:
On “Florence,” Loyle teams up with kwes. to talk about the unborn sister he’s always wanted.

In an interview, Loyle shares his thoughts on “Florence” saying:

I’ve always wanted a little sister. The music speaks for itself…




On September 24th, 2015, Loyle released the visuals for “Florence” that takes place in a kitchen as Carner cooks a delicious breakfast.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7HiB-hNt_mw

Not to mention that Loyle started giving back to his community when he began a cooking school for teens with ADHD.

songs.full_title: Ottolenghi by Loyle Carner (Ft. Jordan Rakei)
songs.title: Ottolenghi

description.plain:
“Ottolenghi” is Loyle Carner’s first main release since his debut studio album Yesterday’s Gone in 2017.

The song’s title references Israeli chef Yotam Ottolenghi who Carner admires greatly. Whilst away, Carner has established his ‘Chili Con Carner’ cooking school for kids with ADHD which he also suffers from himself and so the theme of cooking is prevalent at this time in his life.

After the release of the song, British GQ organized a Christmas cooking show featuring both Carner and Ottolenghi.

songs.full_title: Loose Ends by Loyle Carner (Ft. Jorja Smith)
songs.title: Loose Ends

description.plain:
“Loose Ends” is a deep reflection on Loyle Carner’s adolescence. He expresses that he wished he’d always had the support he has now.

The song features Jorja Smith, who Loyle met at a bar before he was famous.

songs.full_title: The Isle of Arran by Loyle Carner
songs.title: The Isle of Arran

description.plain:
The track is called the Isle of Arran because his grandfather used to live there,  with Carner citing him as one of only a few of his major male role models.

The Isle of Arran is a small island off Ayrshire, on the west  Scotland, famous for its' produce such as skincare products and cheese.

The song was released as the 5th single from his debut album, Yesterday’s Gone.

The beat contains a sample of S.C.I. Youth Choir’s “The Lord Will Make a Way”. Same beat used in Dr. Dre’s “It’s All On Me”.

songs.full_title: Ain't Nothing Changed by Loyle Carner
songs.title: Ain’t Nothing Changed

description.plain: Sampling Italian composer Piero Umiliani’s “Ricordandoti” from the soundtrack to La ragazza dalla pelle di luna, this smooth, jazz-infused track tackles issues surrounding coming of age in the inner-city. Carner  collaborated with director João Retorta on the video for “Ain’t Nothing Changed,” in which Carner is transformed into an old man.

songs.full_title: NO CD by Loyle Carner (Ft. Rebel Kleff)
songs.title: NO CD

description.plain: One of Ben’s more upbeat tracks. In the chorus he describes his love for music and that he spends the money he makes on music instead of, arguably, more important investments for a young man.  Ben and Kleff talk about the music they make and how they enjoy doing it, as well as their dedication and the quality of the music they sample in order to produce the unconventional hip hop that they do.

songs.full_title: Desoleil (Brilliant Corners) by Loyle Carner (Ft. Sampha)
songs.title: Desoleil (Brilliant Corners)

description.plain:
“Desoleil (Brilliant Corners)” is Loyle Carner’s self professed favourite track on the album.
It’s reminiscent of his earlier songs but now he speaks with a new maturity and positive outlook, which is not only how the track sounds, but the general “mise-en-scene” of the song.

Sampha provides some vocals, creating a romantic and nostalgic juxtaposition with Loyle’s fast lyrics.

In the track Loyle, describes growing up since the release of his first album, although still having to face the same struggles he always had. Now however, he has someone to face all of these struggles with. Someone to watch his back or, in Benjamin’s words, “moisture his face when it’s crusty”.

On an Instagram Q & A, Loyle told of how this was the first track made for the album, and that they made it in one day, and the track was a “big deal”.

songs.full_title: Ice Water by Loyle Carner
songs.title: Ice Water

description.plain:
In “Ice Water”, Loyle tells the story of how he met his girlfriend, who is the love of his life and forms one of the album’s consistent themes.

Over the two verses he shows the progression from the infatuation of early stages of a relationship to the fear, doubts and vulnerability that follow.

On May 30th, a live performance of “Ice Water” was uploaded to the COLORS YouTube channel as part of their A COLORS SHOW series.

songs.full_title: Angel by Loyle Carner (Ft. Tom Misch)
songs.title: Angel

description.plain:
“Angel” is a feel-good, upbeat track depicting Loyle’s appreciation of his “haters”. He talks about the hate they give and, using fire as a metaphor, portrays how their doubt acts as “air” for his “fire” and keeps it alive. Keeps him motivated to prove them wrong.

The chorus features a pitched up line by the famous British producer Tom Misch. The line is also spread throughout the track, reiterating how this girl really is his metaphorical angel.

songs.full_title: Dear Ben by Loyle Carner (Ft. Jean Coyle-Larner)
songs.title: Dear Ben

description.plain:
“Dear Ben” is the last track on Not Waving, But Drowning and a heartfelt poem by Loyle Carner’s mother Jean Coyle-Larner.
She talks about Loyle as a child and the importance of his life in her’s as well as their relationship. Reminiscing over childhood and growth of her son Ben (Loyle’s real name) and her struggle to replace the father role after the death of Loyle’s stepfather.

This poem acts as a response to the first track “Dear Jean” in which Loyle writes his own poem to his mother. In it, he reminisces about the past, talks about his girlfriend and tells his mother that he will soon move out of her place. However, he assures her that he will not be gone forever and that he’s thankful and will always love her.

“Dear Ben” also features the same instrumentals als “Dear Jean”, making clear that it’s a response to it.

Loyle’s mother has previously performed a poem on “Sun of Jean” on his album Yesterday’s Gone.

songs.lyrics:
Dear Ben Lyrics[Spoken: Jean Coyle-Larner]
I've watched you grow, from first kick, to first kiss
Shoulder rides to sleepless nights
Felt-tip crows to scoring goals, and bedtime Katamino
Watched you hold your own from boy to man
As you stand firm, bare and bold, not afraid to walk alone
Reveal your pain. Unique. Defiant. Uncompromising
And with our compass lost, we talked long into the darkest hours
Until we saw the burnished sky, and our eyes stung as our words blurred and became thoughts
As we were silenced by the dawn
We clung to each other like sailors in a storm as our world pitched and bucked, our breath stolen by grief
But you stood strong, filled such big boots
Gripped to the helm and steered us on into the calm
Abandoned your lifetime ambition, to hold us down
Took on a different mission, while we were turned inside out, raw and gaping
But you wrapped us up in your dream, realised your vision and fed us with your words of pearl
Like buccaneers, we sailed the seven seas and drank in the wonders of your world, and returned giddy with the heady smell of your success
And when that time came, oh did we weep, but the tears that streaked our cheeks were stained with glee because we knew that this was not goodbye, that you'd be back, that you'd never really left
Because love does not lessen by miles it's not locked out by doors or walls, but reinforced in thought and heart
It cannot be lost like a key or a sock, or left behind in a box, it is present in each and every breath and flows deep with every beat and deed
It may not be your presence but it's your essence that remains. Forever dancing like glitter in our air
And now it's as clear to me my beautiful boy, as naked as the joy that caresses the creases of your eye, that you've finally found your one, your golden snitch, and my task is done
For I've gained a daughter
I've not lost a son

Do you like it?

description.plain: This subjective track cultivates the idea of lust and how we as people rush into new things such as love, fame and earning money. The track shows how Loyle Carner reflects upon his achievements and humbly claims the title of “the lucky one.”

songs.full_title: Krispy by Loyle Carner (Ft. Rebel Kleff)
songs.title: Krispy

description.plain: On “Krispy”, Loyle speaks straight from the heart and talks about his relationship with fellow musician and life long friend Rebel Kleff, also known as Krispy, and how they’ve drifted apart. Today it’s all business, no pleasure and Loyle wishes they could go back to the good old days, when they made music together for fun.

songs.full_title: Tierney Terrace by Loyle Carner
songs.title: Tierney Terrace

description.plain:
“Tierney Terrace” is about the struggles of young Ben Coyle-Larner growing up with large family responsibilities after the death of his step-father.

Loyle Carner told The Guardian,

That’s the most difficult battle of it, because I can never replace my dad – but I can try my best to fill his shoes. Oddly enough, he had size 13 shoes, so I will never quite fill them, but I try my best.

Carner wrote this song after a run in with his biological father. The title of the song is the name of his grandparents' house.

songs.full_title: Dear Jean by Loyle Carner
songs.title: Dear Jean

description.plain: “Dear Jean” is an emotional letter to Loyle Carner’s mother Jean. He reminisces about the past, talks about his girlfriend and tells his mother that he will soon move out of her place. However, he assures her that he will not be gone forever and that he’s thankful and will always love her.

songs.full_title: Sun of Jean by Loyle Carner (Ft. Mum and Dad)
songs.title: Sun of Jean
songs.title_with_featured: Sun of Jean (Ft. Mum and Dad)

description.plain:
The song is all to do with the strong relationship between him and his mother. The title is a double entendre: ‘Son’ of Jean as he is literally her son and ‘Sun’ of Jean as he views his mother and their relationship as very bright.



Carner has frequently told of the prominence of his mother’s role in his life, even bringing her on stage at Glastonbury so that she could hear the crowd cheer as a sonic representation of how much he values her with the help of his fans.

songs.full_title: BFG by Loyle Carner
songs.title: BFG

description.plain:
BFG is the opening track on Carner’s first project A Little Late; the track deals with the grievances he has felt at the passing of his step-father, Steven Vengeance, 7 months prior to the EP’s release.

Carner compares his step-father to The BFG/Big Friendly Giant who is one of English author Roald Dahl’s creations, highlighting the magnitude and presence that the fatherly figure had in his life.

The sample on this track is the song Baby, originally by Donnie and Joe Emerson, covered by Ariel Pink’s Haunted Graffiti.

description.plain: A powerful and rage-filled track, Hate offers insight into what it is to be black, and the loves, seductions and hatreds of Loyle’s life. Loyle grittily exposes the experience of being trapped in racial profiling and the fears he faces.
